thread.title: Seek advice if you demand much: Nutritionist advises pregnant women
thread.title_full: Seek advice if you demand much: Nutritionist advises pregnant women

author: Nwafor Polycarp
title: Seek advice if you demand much: Nutritionist advises pregnant women
text:
Home » News » Seek advice if you demand much: Nutritionist advises pregnant women Seek advice if you demand much: Nutritionist advises pregnant women On 8:03 pm In News by Nwafor Polycarp Comments 
The popular African Star Apple known as Agbalumo or Ciwoh or Udara that most pregnant women crave for has a sour-like taste that holds the mouth, hits the palate and stops one from throwing up or spitting. 
May be these are the main reasons why many pregnant women, who often have these experiences, crave for it. African Star Apple 
A Consultant Nutritionist, Mr Mattehw Felix highlighted the benefits of the seasonal fruit in an interview with journalists in Ikorodu on Monday. 
The fruit, which is botanically called chrysophyllum albidum is mostly cultivated in rural areas and is very common between December and and April. 
Nutritionists say it reduces constipation, sore throat and aids digestion, which are also common problems of pregnant women. 
“It contains more vitamin C than many other fruits; it is rich in calcium, iron potassium, phosphorous, magnesium, tannins, flavonoids, terpenoids, and phytochemicals. 
“Also, it has antioxidant properties that help to fight many deadly diseases. It can also help lower blood sugar and treats heart disease. 
“The fruit has low calorie because of its little fat content, and it is found to be ideal for those who are trying to watch weight because it is high in fibre,” Felix said. 
Felix, however, advised pregnant women to eat the fruit moderately as it could have other harmful effects if consumed too much. 
“If you crave too much for the fruit, seek advice from your care giver,” the consultant advised. Nwafor Polycarp
